body: $TNT Friendly reminder that the stock isn‚Äôt the business and the business isn‚Äôt the stock. Exhibit A
created_at: ENPH back in 2019. Share price declined from $7 to $4 over the course of 5 months (I believe stock was hit with similar short report/ manipulation at this time). Stock then proceeded to go from $4 to $280 over the course of 2 years. Why? Market caught up to the business growth. Financials for Enphase were similar to Tenets back then. At $4 for ENPH you were paying about $500-$600M for a company giving you ~400M of run-rate revenue
column3: growing about 100%+ YoY and moving from unprofitable to profitable. Today they have a $20B market cap after a large market correction on a run-rate of about $1.2B of revenue and $110M of net income (hmm those numbers sound very familiar ?). I bet those people who bought ENPH at $7 and experienced pain for 5 months as they watched their accounts go down 50% are pretty happy they held the stock. Time in market > timing the market.

$TNT and I'm going to repeat this again and again:
- Fed thermo nuke the market with a huge rate hike during a mid term election year?

Unlikely. More likely in fact they do little to nothing and make it look like their doing something. So in that case 2021 saw small caps and growth hammered you'd see the opposite in a reality where inflation growth beyond normal is an accepted reality as the rich arent going to nuke their own assets to "help out" the working class with inflation.
Know how I know? I hang out with the 1% of the 1% in the SF Bay and they ain't nuking their own shit to help out hourly employees--- as much as they bluster progressivism.

$TNT my thing isnt going to change here--- the co either is seeing explosive growth and has a forecast to grow in multiples in the coming years or not multiplied with tiny mkt cap and small float.....
All this macro BS and FUD aside it's that or it's not and I have yet to see a bear case beyond "mgmt didnt SEC right PR wahhhh"...
K. Hold.
